title: 112_hr2610
content: The Act may be cited as the "Asset Forfeiture Fund Reform and Distribution Act of 2011". It focuses on reforming the asset forfeiture fund. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to specify the distribution of payments for violations, based on the location of the violation or the homeport of the vessel involved. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act specifies the distribution of payments for violations based on the location of the violation or the homeport of the vessel involved. Amounts paid to a State shall be used for research and monitoring activities related to marine fisheries management. The amendments made by subsection (a) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act include compensation for analyzing economic impacts of fishery management decisions, monitoring fishing activities, preparing fishery impact statements, and other activities deemed necessary by Regional Fishery Management Councils. These amendments apply to amounts received under section 311(e) of the Act after September 30, 2011. The Secretary may use fisheries enforcement penalties received before October 1, 2011, to reimburse legal fees and costs up to $200,000 per person. Covered persons must submit an application for reimbursement by December 31, 2011. The Secretary must make a final determination on reimbursement within 60 days of receiving an application. 80% of remaining funds after reimbursements are for fishery stock assessments in the management region. The Secretary determines appropriate legal fees and costs for covered persons challenging fisheries enforcement penalties within 30 days. 20% of funds go to States under Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The Secretary determines legal fees and costs for covered persons challenging fisheries enforcement penalties within 30 days. A covered person is defined as someone directed to receive a remittance of a fisheries enforcement penalty. The term "Decision Memorandum" refers to the Secretarial Decision Memorandum issued by the Secretary on May 17, 2011, titled "Decisions regarding Certain NOAA Fisheries Enforcement Cases Based on Special Master Swartwood's Report and Recommendations." The term "fisheries enforcement penalty" is defined as a penalty paid, a complaint submitted before May 7, 2011, seeking remittance of the penalty, and the Secretary directing remittance of the penalty or a portion of it. The term "fisheries enforcement penalty" refers to any fine, penalty, or forfeiture imposed for violating marine resource laws enforced by the Secretary of Commerce, including the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act and the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON ADMINISTRATIVE LAW JUDGES IN NOAA: The Administrator of NOAA cannot assign proceedings to an administrative law judge who has served for five or more years in the same fishery management region. Reassignment is allowed after five years. SEC. 4. DEFINITION OF FISHERY MANAGEMENT REGION. The term "fishery management region" in this Act refers to a region under the jurisdiction of a Regional Fishery Management Council established under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act.
